content.text: THE modish, minimalist décor tips you off that things are a little different at Zoma, a new Ethiopian restaurant just north of Central Park on Fredrick Douglass Boulevard.  The azifa confirms it.  At Zoma, that well-spiced heap of lentil salad flecked through with onions and chilies ($4) isn't served on injera flatbread as it is elsewhere. Instead, it arrives at the table cradled in leaves of endive, like a canapé you might poach from a passed platter at a cocktail party.  It's one of the touches that give the food at Zoma a tonier, more citified treatment than it gets at other Ethiopian restaurants in New York.  The proprietors employ broad white platters instead of the more traditional metal trays and have a short beer, wine and cocktail list.  Dishes like tibs wett, beef and the spice mix called berbere slowly simmered into a delicious whole, are more lightly sauced, not swimming in spice-infused butter ($13). It's not Ethiopian lite, per se, it's just that the kitchen manages to avoid the warm, welcoming arms of buttery overkill. Even the injera seems a little healthier: it's a shade or two darker than some and a touch less spongy than most. Butter and relative sponginess aside, the kitchen's sure hand with spice and seasoning ensures that flavor is never in short supply.  The combination platters are the best way to sample a range of dishes and are the best values by a stretch. The menu says they feed two, but, with an appetizer, there's plenty for three.  The vegetarian combination ($17) includes heaping dollops of all seven vegetable and legume preparations from the menu. Each is clean and distinct, but the shiro wett, toasted and ground legumes boldly seasoned and simmered forever in the berbere-flavored wett sauce, struck the strongest chord.  The shiro wett (the spelling used here, though it is sometimes rendered wat or wot) showed up again on the doro wett combination platter ($19). The doro wett is a mess of chicken drumsticks that have seen the same simmering and spicing treatment as the other wett dishes, and is the best meat preparation at Zoma. The night I tried it, the chicken was cooked to a perfect point of tenderness. It yielded to just the tiniest tug of injera-enrobed fingers, slipping off into the assertive and buttery (but not too buttery) sauce.  You might be tempted to wash down the meal with a bottle of tej, Ethiopian-style honey wine made by Brotherhood Winery in Washingtonville, N.Y., or with some of the restaurant's custom cocktails. But unless drinks like supersweet one-dimensional wine or a Harlem Raging Bull cocktail (Red Bull, tequila, vodka and lime) are your idea of good companions to food, it might be best to stick to beer or wine. (The only thing wrong with a friend's martini was its bathtub-like size, though that might not be a bad thing, depending on what you need to do the next morning.)  The dining room at Zoma can feel unwelcoming when it's empty -- a sea of wobbly black tables set against sparsely adorned walls.  A stepped lightbox on the back bar doubles as a display for bottles of booze and as one of the chief sources of illumination in the room. As a result the votive candles on the table are a must for reading the menu.  But as the room fills up -- and it does seem to be popular enough already to fill up around 9 p.m. some nights -- it warms up. And the well-intentioned, if occasionally overwhelmed, servers are quick with a smile regardless of the hour.  Zoma  2084 Frederick Douglass Boulevard (113th Street), Harlem; (212) 662-0620.  BEST DISHES -- Doro wett, shiro wett, both dishes with collard greens in them.  PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers, $4 to $6; main courses, $7 to $15; combination platters, $17 to $19.  CREDIT CARDS -- Visa and MasterCard.  HOURS -- Monday though Thursday, 4 p.m. to 11 p.m.; Friday, Saturday and Sunday, noon to 11 p.m.  WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- All on one level.  $25 AND UNDER

content.text: Less than a square mile in area, NoHo, short for north of Houston, is a stroller's paradise, with wide cobblestone streets and few cars. Though zoning rules have limited the types of businesses that can occupy ground floors, restaurants are trickling in, broadening the food options.  BIANCA  (212) 260-4666; 5 Bleecker Street (Bowery); $; Diner's Journal: 2/20/04.  Bianca, an inexpensive and charming neighborhood restaurant, evokes an Italian latteria, or dairy store, as outfitted by someone with a keen eye for architectural detail.  The menu is from Emilia-Romagna, in Northern Italy, with plates of delicate, fragrant gnocco fritto, or yeasty, pillow-shaped fritters, served alongside dabs of stracchino cheese or fans of salume: coppa, mortadella, salami and silky prosciutto di Parma.  CHINATOWN BRASSERIE  * [Rating: One Star]  (212) 533-7000; 380 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street); $$$; Review: 8/9/06.  Chinatown Brasserie takes dim sum seriously. The executive chef Joe Ng's thoughtful, prolific output includes not only soup dumplings but also steamed dumplings filled with shrimp and snow pea leaf. Chinatown Brasserie offers pork pot stickers as well as green chili peppers stuffed with shrimp and encased in tempura batter.  HEDEH  (212) 473-8458; 57 Great Jones Street (Bowery); $$; Article: 9/29/04.  Hedeh's sleek bar is decorated with rows of sake bottles. The dining room has a menu of sushi and sashimi along with fusion dishes like shrimp with spinach and red miso sauce; salmon with red beans in a soy milk sauce; fillet of beef with chive oil and tofu sauce; and green-tea crème brûlée.  IL BUCO  * [Rating: One Star]  (212) 533-1932; 47 Bond Street (Lafayette Street); $$$; Review: 5/3/96, Diner's Journal: 10/21/05.  The building that houses Il Buco once belonged to a friend of Edgar Allan Poe, and the cellar supposedly inspired ''The Cask of Amontillado.'' The Mediterranean menu is as beguiling as the antiques-strewn dining room. Most of a short list of main courses changes daily, but there are some standards like slow-roasted heritage pork with wild arugula salad and quince mustard; and grilled sirloin steak with red wine, onion marmalade, Yukon potatoes and romesco.  SPARKY'S ALL-AMERICAN FOOD  (212) 334-3035; 333 Lafayette (Bleecker Street); $; $25 and Under: 12/28/05.  Sparky's steamed organic all-beef hot dogs, from Dines Farms in Oak Hill, N.Y., nestled in fresh-baked buns from Amy's Bread, are the top of the pile. Juicy without being mushy, they can practically be eaten plain, though Sparky's offers dressed-up dogs, including one with blue cheese and Buffalo wings sauce and the Sparky dog with chili, cheese, bacon and onions.  GOOD EATING/NOHO

content.text: OFF the menu. Have sweeter words ever been spoken, especially by New Yorkers? We all believe we deserve something more special than the people at the next table, and who's to say we're wrong?  But it's more than a smidgen of foie gras or an extra shaving of truffles that constitutes this particular thrill. It's a dish of one's own, homey enough that the imaginary mommy of your dreams might have cooked it, yet eaten in the midst of a social swirl.  And the good news is, it's not only for regulars, those not-so-secret favorite children of restaurateurs. Mere mortals have a chance, too.  My favorite off-the-menu moment last year happened not in New York but in Yountville, Calif. I had spent three days in San Francisco before eating at Redd, a new restaurant in the Napa Valley. It was the fourth dinner of a two-week vacation, and the reductions and the foams were already piling up.  Our waitress approached. ''Is there anything not on the menu?'' my husband said, asking about the specials. She considered. ''I think we have some meatballs in the kitchen,'' she said. I saw her then surrounded by a golden aura, like an angel from a prayer card.  ''You have meatballs?'' I asked furtively. I felt as if I were scoring dope in the schoolyard.  She checked with the chef to be sure.  ''We do, and we're happy to serve them as a middle course,'' she said.  Who knows what accounted for our windfall -- a new restaurant wooing repeat customers or a kitchen burdened with too many leftovers -- but we were ecstatic. The meatballs were feather light, in a richly flavorful brown sauce, nestled alongside homemade egg pasta.  The dish was so unexpected, so deliciously satisfying, that I cannot remember my entree. But five months later I'm still thinking about those meatballs.  In October, with a group of friends, I ate at Primola, an Italian restaurant on Second Avenue between 64th and 65th Streets. Midway through I noticed a woman at our table devouring a work of art: veal chop parmigiana, well done. It covered a platter and looked like a beautiful pizza. I wouldn't rest until I had one of my own, so we returned to the restaurant with her and her husband a few weeks ago. ''Where is it?'' I asked, dismayed, scanning the menu.  She looked blank. ''I have no idea,'' she said. ''Every time I come, I just order it.'' As we did. It lived up to its promise, a thin-crust pizza, the thin crust made of meat.  Italian restaurants, it seems, are almost always amenable to serving off the menu. A friend of mine is a regular at Sistina, also on Second Avenue, between 80th and 81st Streets, where he is addicted to what he calls nut pasta.  This turns out to be an off-the-menu favorite of the owner, Giuseppe Bruno, who first ate it on the Lipari Islands, near Sicily. A basic tomato sauce is mixed with a pesto of four kinds of raw nuts, which makes a creamless pink sauce with real body, enlivened by the kick of black and red peppers, a generous grating of pecorino and a few ribbons of fresh mint.  It's a crazy combination of bar food -- nuts and cheese -- with noodles, and while it's hard to figure out why it works, it's easy to eat a bowlful as you think about it (though not exactly cheap: $12 as an appetizer, $20 as an entree). He started serving it to regulars who wanted what he was eating, Mr. Bruno said, but he will prepare the dish for anyone who requests it when making a reservation.  Being a regular, after all, does not guarantee access to all of a restaurant's secrets. I recently sat at the bar at the Union Square Cafe, a place I consider a home away from home, and while paying the check saw an astonishing sight.  For the 21 years I've been going there, it has served a steak with mashed potatoes, a combination my mom used to make. I'm not a huge steak fan, so I rarely think about it. But that night, as I watched a vision go by -- a plate of steak heaped with the most beautifully bronzed, perfectly cut frites -- I flagged down a bartender.  ''If they have it in the kitchen, they'll do it for you,'' he said. (If they have what? Potatoes? There are no fries on the dinner menu.) I stared obsessively at the unsuspecting diner tucking in a few seats away, and fought the urge to go sit in his lap. Steak and mashed potatoes is just like home. But steak and French fries? That's Saturday night.  Now I won't rest until I have them. Even on a Tuesday.  Bucatini With Raw Nut Pesto and Tomato Sauce (Bucatini alla Lipari)  Adapted from Sistina Restaurant  Time: About 40 minutes  For the tomato sauce:  1/4 cup olive oil  1 medium onion, finely chopped  1 clove garlic, finely chopped  1 pound (about 2 cups) canned whole peeled tomatoes, with juice  Salt and freshly ground black pepper  For the pesto:  2 garlic cloves, crushed  2 teaspoons hot red pepper flakes  5 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil  2 cups mixed whole raw nuts, like pine nuts, walnuts, pistachios and hazelnuts  3 to 4 leaves of fresh mint  Freshly ground black pepper  For the pasta:  Salt  1 pound bucatini  Fresh mint leaves, for garnish  Grated sheep's milk pecorino.  1.  For tomato sauce: In a heavy-based saucepan over medium heat, heat oil and sauté onion until translucent. Add garlic and tomatoes with their juices, breaking up the tomatoes with a wooden spoon. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Simmer uncovered until most of the juices have evaporated, 20 to 30 minutes. Meanwhile, prepare pesto.  2.  For pesto: In a food processor, combine garlic, hot pepper flakes, olive oil, nuts and mint. Pulse to make a smooth paste (a slightly coarse nut butter). Season with black pepper to taste and set aside.  3.  For pasta: Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add bucatini and cook until al dente (firm to the bite). Set aside  1/2 cup pasta water, and drain pasta well. Return pasta to the warm pot and add pesto and tomato sauce. Toss well to coat, adding reserved water as needed to thin the sauce. Transfer to a warm serving bowl and garnish with fresh mint leaves. Serve with pecorino cheese passed separately.  Yield: 4 servings.  FEED ME

content.text: WELCOME back, Chaophaya. The Thai restaurant reopened in its new quarters in Kings Park in mid-November. It had a near-cult following during its eight years in Lindenhurst before closing abruptly two years ago. (There was a problem with the lease, the owners said.)  The Kings Park restaurant is on Main Street, a big improvement over its previous, hard-to-find location. The building had been home to the American Bistro, then to a series of Italian restaurants. With Chaophaya, its revolving-door days may be over.  The restaurant is owned by two talented sisters: Molrude (Neena) Kittiratanaporn, the chef, and Noi Bartolomeo, who rules the front of the house. Various family members are on hand on busy nights, greeting patrons, running the bar, waiting on tables and helping out in the kitchen. Their talents are not limited to the culinary arts. Our waitress told us that everything in the dining room had been made by the family: the wooden tables, the metal wall sconces and other decorations. One wall depicts Thai temples highlighted in metallic paint; another features wooden boxes with water running over pebbles.  Noi Bartolomeo, elegantly dressed in Thai style, is a dynamo. She does a fine job of explaining the menu, determining how spicy patrons want their food to be and noting any other dining preferences. The rest of the staff is amiable but quite casual. The runner delivering dishes does not know who ordered them, and it may take more than one request to get a soft drink refill.  Still, it is the exceptionally good food that is the big story here. Chaophaya's pad Thai was the best I have ever eaten. The stir-fried rice noodles were moist, crunchy with bean sprouts and slightly sweet; they were enhanced by a crown of four jumbo shrimp. A squeeze from an accompanying wedge of lime made the dish perfect. A rival for top honors was called spicy noodle, which we ordered with beef. These wide, flat noodles were full of flavor from basil and chilies.  Soups were standouts. All carried a red star on the menu, indicating spiciness. Even though we requested them mild, they still delivered a kick. The tom yum koong, a clear shrimp soup, provided a tangy hit from lime juice and lemongrass. The tom ka kai, a vibrant chicken soup, had its heat tempered by coconut milk.  Both the beef and shrimp salads were outstanding starters for those who like their food spicy. They sparkled with crunchy fresh ingredients. We did have to ask for knives for the beef salad; the slices of meat were far larger than bite-size.  Other appetizers that scored were Thai dumplings, both the delicate, nearly transparent vegetable variety and the sturdier ones filled with meat. Shrimp blanket was another good pick. It consisted of four whole shrimp enclosed in egg roll wrappers and served with plum sauce.  Don't miss the whole baked fish (boned) in a sweet-tangy tamarind sauce. It was perched atop baby bok choy and slices of eggplant. The sautéed Asian eggplant with basil in garlic sauce was also splendid.  The two best curries sampled were the pad pik khing with chicken, string beans and lime leaves, and the sea scallops with coconut milk and chilies in a red curry sauce. We tried two versions of pad kaprow. One starred a crunchy mix of vegetables, chili peppers, garlic, onions and basil with shrimp; the other featured tofu. Both delivered.  My favorite desserts were the fried ice cream with raspberry sauce, served aflame, and the fried bananas. The latter were small, crisp logs wrapped in spring roll skins and drizzled with honey and sesame seeds. The tapioca was hot and flecked with black beans, not the cold Western pudding. Tapioca fans loved it anyway. Slices of fresh mango surrounding a mound of not-too-sweet sticky rice was another pleaser. Skip the three Thai fruits listed on the menu, longans, rambutans and litchis, all canned in syrup; they all tasted the same.  Chaophaya's loyal following continues to grow. As I left the restaurant, I heard the people at the next table tell the waitress they were visiting for the third time that week.  Chaophaya  25 Main Street (Route 25A)  Kings Park  (631) 269-2818  VERY GOOD  THE SPACE -- Simply decorated, with Thai touches. There are a few steps at the entrance to the restaurant, but restrooms are wheelchair accessible.  THE CROWD -- Mainly families and couples.  THE BAR -- A separate room, at the entrance, is dominated by a long wooden bar. The restaurant is still awaiting a license to serve wine and beer. Diners may bring their own.  THE BILL -- Complete lunch with Thai salad and spring roll, $7.95 to $8.95. Dinner entrees, $8.95 to $16.95.  WHAT WE LIKE -- Thai dumplings, shrimp blanket, tom yum koong, tom ka kai, beef salad, shrimp salad; pad pik khing, sea scallop curry, pad kaprow with tofu, pad kaprow with shrimp, baked whole fish in tamarind sauce, pad Thai with shrimp, spicy noodle with beef, eggplant with basil; fried ice cream, fried bananas.  IF YOU GO -- Open noon till 10 p.m. Sunday and Tuesday through Thursday, till 11 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Closed Monday. Reservations are recommended.  DINING/KINGS PARK
